Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Story: I stared at my phone, thumb hovering over the screen. My stepdad had just texted, “Hope you’re having a good weekend. Let us know if you want to come by for dinner.” I knew he and Mom expected me to check in, even if it was just a quick message. They always said it made them feel included in my life. But just as I started typing a reply, my phone buzzed again—this time, it was Alex. “Can we talk? I feel weird about what happened earlier,” she wrote. We’d had a small argument about our plans, and I could tell she wanted to resolve it right away. She hated leaving things unsettled, and I didn’t want her to think I didn’t care. My heart pounded as I looked between the two conversations, feeling pulled in opposite directions. I wanted to be a good daughter, but I also wanted to be a supportive girlfriend. The pressure built in my chest as I tried to figure out who needed me more in that moment, and what I should do first.
